editorialDecl.p: Edgeworth’s spelling and punctuation are retained in transcription, including non-standard spelling, line breaks, and hyphenation of words. The long s and ligatured forms are silently emended.

div.p:
Mr. Mill and M.r Ricardo hold
a doctrine about Rewards wy no re-
ward reward can be given to one person
without injury to some other
person or class of persons - by
inju
ry injury
here includes the idea of restrain
-ing restraining their liberty - diminishing their
privileges - or enjoyments -
Perhaps I should express the doctrine
more exactly by saying that they
expect that you cannot give a re -ward reward to one person without it's
being at the expense of some other or other
- I argued this point with Ricardo & he
gave up - but I never had an opportunity
of stating any argument to Mill - What do
you think of this doctrine? - Take a crown of
parsley for instance as your reward.

When you have time to think
for me will you next consider my Dr
friend whether travelling & The Travellers
would make a good subject for a
story for me to write - the rage for travelling
you know is prevalent - Eyes & no Eyes-
Ears and no ears - The affectation - The
ignorance - The ill humor - The national
& personal prejudices pulling different ways of a party of travellers
might be drawn - the advantages & disadvan
-tages disadvantages to their country & to their own happiness
must be shown - You will see in a moment all
that can be made of the subject - wd you advise me to
follow or abandon it - I will not begintill I have yr answer
